question.title: Do I need synchronise on objects which guarantee happen-before?

node.contents: I have a collection which guaranteed to be visible across threads. However that doesn't guarantee visibility of states of items which are stored in this collection(eg. if I have collection of StringBuilder(mutable, not thread safe) then I have to synchronize on each item in collection during write/read, right?). So, what happens when I have collection of objects which are used for guaranteeing happen-before by themselves(eg. countdownlatch). Do I need to synchronize on each item somehow when calling await/countDown? Code below roughly illustrate this dilemma:

astNode.text: I have a collection which guaranteed to be visible across threads. However that doesn't guarantee visibility of states of items which are stored in this collection(eg. if I have collection of StringBuilder(mutable, not thread safe) then I have to synchronize on each item in collection during write/read, right?). So, what happens when I have collection of objects which are used for guaranteeing happen-before by themselves(eg. countdownlatch). Do I need to synchronize on each item somehow when calling await/countDown? Code below roughly illustrate this dilemma:

elements.contents: public class SyncQuestion { final List<CountDownLatch> lathces = new ArrayList<CountDownLatch>(); SyncQuestion() { lathces.add(new CountDownLatch(1)); } public static void main(String[] args) throws InterruptedException { final SyncQuestion sync = new SyncQuestion(); final Thread sleepingThread = new Thread() { public void run() { for (CountDownLatch latch : sync.lathces) { try { latch.await(); } catch (InterruptedException e) { throw new RuntimeException(e); } } }; }; final Thread wakingThread = new Thread() { public void run() { for (CountDownLatch latch : sync.lathces) { latch.countDown(); } }; }; sleepingThread.start(); wakingThread.start(); sleepingThread.join(); wakingThread.join(); }

units.rawText:
public class SyncQuestion { final List<CountDownLatch> lathces = new ArrayList<CountDownLatch>(); SyncQuestion() { lathces.add(new CountDownLatch(1)); } public static void main(String[] args) throws InterruptedException { final SyncQuestion sync = new SyncQuestion(); final Thread sleepingThread = new Thread() { public void run() { for (CountDownLatch latch : sync.lathces) { try { latch.await(); } catch (InterruptedException e) { throw new RuntimeException(e); } } }; }; final Thread wakingThread = new Thread() { public void run() { for (CountDownLatch latch : sync.lathces) { latch.countDown(); } }; }; sleepingThread.start(); wakingThread.start(); sleepingThread.join(); wakingThread.join(); } ...
}

node.contents: Please correct me in my assumptions, if they are wrong.

astNode.text: Please correct me in my assumptions, if they are wrong.

node.contents: Thanks Cameron. Though your answer is correct I accepted one from Matt because of more detailed explanation(really helps me).

astNode.text: Thanks Cameron. Though your answer is correct I accepted one from Matt because of more detailed explanation(really helps me).

node.contents: I don't believe you need to manually synchronize in this case because the latches are internally thread-safe.

astNode.text: I don't believe you need to manually synchronize in this case because the latches are internally thread-safe.

node.contents: A CountDownLatch is basically a wrapper on AbstractQueuedSynchronizer whose state is a volatile int that is mutated via Unsafe.compareAndSwapInt (which is an atomic operation).

astNode.text: A CountDownLatch is basically a wrapper on AbstractQueuedSynchronizer whose state is a volatile int that is mutated via Unsafe.compareAndSwapInt (which is an atomic operation).

node.contents: Therefore in this specific case, as Cameron Skinner said, there is no need to synchronize because it enforces that happens-before for you.

astNode.text: Therefore in this specific case, as Cameron Skinner said, there is no need to synchronize because it enforces that happens-before for you.
